transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Hello everyone! Welcome to our session today. I’m really glad to see all of you here. Before we dive in, let’s take a moment to check in with each other. How’s everyone feeling right now? No need to hold back.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’m feeling okay, a bit tired though. Lots of schoolwork this week.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I’m a little stressed. We had a big assignment due yesterday.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’m good, mostly. Just feeling a little anxious about exams coming up.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I’m fine. Excited to be here. Football practice was intense today.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’m feeling nervous. I’ve got a lot going on at home.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’m okay. Just a normal day, nothing too special.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thank you all for sharing. It’s really important to notice how we’re feeling, because it helps us understand how we show up to challenges. Today, we’re going to explore a really powerful idea called a growth mindset. Has anyone heard that term before?

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I think so. Is it about believing you can get better at something if you work at it?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, exactly, Jabari! That’s a great start. A growth mindset is the understanding that our abilities, intelligence, and talents aren’t fixed. They can grow and improve with effort, learning, and persistence. It’s different from a fixed mindset, which is the belief that our abilities are set in stone and can’t change.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: So it’s like our brain is a muscle, and the more we exercise it, the stronger it gets?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Amani. That’s a perfect analogy. When you challenge yourself, learn from mistakes, and keep trying, your brain literally builds new connections, much like strengthening a muscle through repeated exercise.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: But what if you fail a lot? Doesn’t that mean you’re just not good at it?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Not at all, Keziah. Failure is not a reflection of who you are—it’s a signal that you’re learning. Each mistake is an opportunity to adjust your strategy and grow. It’s like learning to ride a bike. You don’t start off perfectly, and every fall teaches you something.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I get that, but it’s hard to feel that way when you mess up in front of people.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Absolutely, Leo. It can feel uncomfortable, even embarrassing. A growth mindset doesn’t remove those feelings, but it helps you see that the feeling is temporary, and the focus is on improvement rather than perfection.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: So struggling with something doesn’t mean I’m not smart?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Sara. Struggling is your brain learning. It’s evidence that you’re pushing your limits and creating new pathways in your mind.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’ve always thought you’re either good at something or not. So this means I can actually get better at things I’m not good at now?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, Sam. Anyone can improve with effort, practice, and using effective strategies. Talent is not fixed—it grows.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Can you give a real example? Something that actually happened to someone?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sure. Think about someone like Serena Williams. She didn’t become a tennis champion overnight. She practiced every single day, learned from her losses, listened to her coaches, and kept improving. The hard work, persistence, and reflection made the difference, not just natural talent.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: So even really talented people get better because they work at it?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly. Talent might give you a starting point, but growth comes from effort and persistence. And it’s not just athletes—it’s in school, arts, music, and life skills too.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Sometimes I study a lot and still don’t get good grades. Does that mean I’m not capable?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Not at all, Keziah. Growth mindset isn’t just about trying hard—it’s about trying smart. Using strategies, reflecting on what didn’t work, seeking help, and adjusting your approach are all part of growth. Effort plus strategy equals improvement.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: So failing a test isn’t the end of the world—it’s just feedback?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Leo. Feedback is information for growth, not a judgment on your worth or intelligence.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: It still feels frustrating sometimes though.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s completely normal, Sara. Frustration is part of learning. The growth mindset doesn’t remove frustration, but it helps you use that feeling to try different strategies, reflect, and move forward.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: So it’s like switching your thinking from 'I can’t do this' to 'I can learn to do this'?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Sam. That shift in mindset changes how you approach challenges and setbacks.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I usually give up if I fail something. I’ll try thinking differently next time.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s a great start, Jabari. Recognizing the opportunity to try again is a key part of growth mindset.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Can we do an activity to practice this?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Absolutely. Let’s do a reflection exercise. Think of something you struggled with recently—school, sports, a hobby, anything. Write down what didn’t go as planned.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Okay, I’ll write about football practice today.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’ll write about my math homework.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll do drawing. My sketch didn’t turn out as I hoped.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Piano practice for me. I kept making mistakes.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Science project. Didn’t get the results I expected.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I’ll write about language practice. I kept forgetting words.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Great. Now, next to each struggle, write one thing you could try differently next time—a small step or strategy to improve.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I could practice plays slowly before trying full speed.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I could ask my teacher for extra examples and practice problems.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll break down drawings into smaller steps.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll practice tricky parts of my piano song separately.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I could redo my experiment in smaller steps.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I’ll review new words in short daily sessions.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Excellent ideas. You’re already applying growth mindset thinking: focusing on effort, reflection, and strategy rather than worrying about being perfect.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Feels more doable when I think in small steps.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Yeah, less overwhelming that way.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: Makes mistakes feel less scary.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I get it now. Effort plus strategy matters more than just natural ability.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll try that next time I fail something.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: It turns frustration into action.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly. That’s the essence of a growth mindset. For homework, notice when you’re thinking in a fixed mindset and practice reframing it into growth mindset thinking. A small journal is a great tool for this.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Just a few sentences each day, right?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, Leo. The goal is awareness and small practice, not long writing.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: That seems manageable.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: Yeah, I can do that.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Same here.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll try.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Me too.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Wonderful. Let’s take a moment to share one example of how you might use growth mindset this week. Who wants to start?

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: If I mess up a football drill, I’ll practice it in small steps rather than getting frustrated.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’ll ask my teacher for help in math instead of assuming I’m bad at it.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll redo my drawings in parts when frustrated.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Focus on tricky piano sections first, then the full song.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Redo small parts of my science project instead of giving up.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Review new language words daily instead of cramming.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Excellent. Remember, growth mindset isn’t about being perfect—it’s about effort, reflection, and persistence. Keep noticing your thoughts, practice reframing challenges, and celebrate small improvements. Thank you all for your participation today. I’m proud of the effort and reflection you’ve all shown. See you next session!
